14 years ago, 
@Astro_Mike
 wrote the first tweet from space. Since then, we’ve been sharing snippets of our life in orbit—and what it’s like to gaze upon our home planet.

Follow along: http://nasa.gov/astronauts/biographies/active…

This 
@NASAWebb
 image of the Pillars of Creation helps astronomers determine how stars form. Plus, it makes pretty sweet digital wallpaper.

Download high-resolution images from https://webbtelescope.org.

When the Relativity Space Terran 1 rocket lit up the night sky as it launched this past March, it became the first 3D-printed rocket test of its kind. Learn about GRCop—an innovative, high strength material at the center of this breakthrough: https://go.nasa.gov/44igKrA

Over their eight days on the @Space_Station, the private astronauts of @Axiom_Space's Axiom Mission 2 will run activities from student outreach to scientific experiments.

#Ax2 is set to lift off from @NASAKennedy on Sunday, May 21—here's how to watch: https://go.nasa.gov/41yAdlp

LIVE: Cosmonauts are about to embark on a spacewalk to deploy and activate a radiator that will help cool the @Space_Station’s Nauka science module: http://nasa.gov/live

New images from @NASAPersevere may show evidence of what was once a wild and deep river on Mars. The observations are leading scientists to rethink how ancient water once flowed on the Red Planet. https://go.nasa.gov/41tYxEP

This @NASAWebb image of the Pillars of Creation helps astronomers determine how stars form. Plus, it makes pretty sweet digital wallpaper.

Download high-resolution images from https://webbtelescope.org.
Solid answers, good job everybody. And as for us? We love exploring, but there's no place like home.

Astronaut Kjell Lindgren has been a crewmember on the @Space_Station for two long-duration stays. His work during those expeditions helps keep crew safe and healthy and directly contributes to our goal of going to Mars. #AANHPIHeritageMonth https://go.nasa.gov/42DHp0r
Throughout May, we’ll celebrate #AANHPIHeritageMonth by honoring some of the brilliant people who shape NASA and inspire generations: https://go.nasa.gov/3aVaglx

Tale as old as time. 

Unusual asteroid Phaethon behaves like a comet. It brightens and forms a tail as it nears the Sun and is the source of a meteor shower, something usually led by comets. But this asteroid's tail tells a different story:
https://go.nasa.gov/3LHmtQs

This week at NASA, astronauts prepped the @Space_Station for more solar arrays, @NASAHubble celebrated its 33rd anniversary with a new image of a dark nebula, and @VP and @President_KR visited @NASAGoddard.
TROPICS Launch Update!

Astronauts Steve Bowen and @Astro_Alneyadi concluded today’s seven-hour spacewalk at 4:12 p.m. ET (20:12 UTC). It was the eighth for Bowen and the first for any UAE astronaut: https://go.nasa.gov/3ADIeuf

Live: TROPICS experts discuss the mission, which aims to improve understanding of tropical cyclones through regular measurements of precipitation, temperature & humidity.
 
Use #AskNASA and your questions may get answered on air.

Today's spacewalk is officially underway! The two astronauts have switched their spacesuits to battery power. Steve Bowen of @NASA_Astronauts and @Astro_Alneyadi will route power cables to prepare for future power system upgrades outside the @Space_Station.
LIVE: It's spacewalk time. Watch with us as Steve Bowen of @NASA_Astronauts and @Astro_Alneyadi work on upgrades to the @Space_Station's power system.
Two cosmonauts will conduct a pair of spacewalks on Wednesday, May 3, and Friday, May 12, to relocate hardware outside the @Space_Station. Details and coverage info: https://go.nasa.gov/44blzDe

Whistles. Crunches. Whooshes.

These are a few of the space sounds heard in a new citizen science project called HARP.
By participating, you can investigate cosmic vibrations recorded by NASA spacecraft that help sing the song of the Sun and Earth.

More: http://go.nasa.gov/3mDXm7o

Shine bright like a ULIRG 

With the light of a trillion suns, an ultra-luminous infrared galaxy (ULIRG) shines in the latest 
@NASAWebb
 image. Located 250 million light-years away, this target is actually the result of two colliding spiral galaxies: https://go.nasa.gov/3L7dojN

Having trouble sleeping? Try some of these seven techniques our astronauts use to get better sleep in space!
 
These methods help 
@NASA_Astronauts
 sleep well through the disruptions of their natural sleep cycle — and they may help you too: https://go.nasa.gov/3MNWYhA

Last year was pretty busy. 

We launched to the Moon. We yeeted a spacecraft into an asteroid (on purpose.) And we unveiled images from a brand new space telescope. NBD. 

Oh yeah, we also nabbed nine noms for the #Webbys. If you like what you saw, vote? http://go.nasa.gov/3KBXNZl
